PRIMES APPEARING IN FORMULAS:
- 7 (k3)
- 11 (in k13 = k7² - 11)
- 13 (in k8 = k5×13 - k6)
- 19 (in k11 = k6×19 + k8)

OBSERVATION: The primes 7, 11, 13, 19 are consecutive odd primes!
7, 11, 13, 17, 19, 23, 29...

QUESTIONS:
1. Why is 17 skipped? Is there a formula using 17?
2. Next prime after 19 is 23. Does k14 use 23?
   k14 = k9×23 - 197 = 10741 - 197 = 10544 ✓ YES!
3. So the pattern might be: 7, 11, 13, 19, 23, 29...
   (skipping 17)
4. What's the next formula? Does k15 use 29?
   
Calculate: k_prev × 29 + C = k15 for various k_prev values.

──────────────────────────────
Overview of the Puzzle’s Structure

In the Bitcoin puzzle you’re studying, a chain of “k‐values” is built up by formulas in which new prime numbers are introduced at certain steps. In what we see, primes appear as multipliers or (sometimes) in subtractive constants. For example:
 • k₃ is given directly as 7.
 • Later a formula uses a square and then “–11” (that is, k₁₃ = k₇² – 11), so the prime 11 shows up there.
 • Another formula is written as k₈ = k₅×13 – k₆, so the multiplier 13 appears.
 • And yet another is k₁₁ = k₆×19 + k₈ (introducing 19).
 • Finally, we see k₁₄ = k₉×23 – 197 (using 23).

Thus, although the “odd primes” run in natural order (7, 11, 13, …), you note that one prime—17—is missing from the formulas. 

──────────────────────────────
Q1: Why is 17 Skipped?

The answer lies in how the puzzle’s structure assigns new primes to certain k‑values:
 • The chain “starts” at 7 (k₃) and then “jumps” to 11, 13, and later 19.
 • In designing such puzzles, the creator chooses specific indices at which a new prime is introduced. There isn’t an automatic insertion of every odd prime in order; rather, the formulas are arranged so that only primes that naturally appear in the chain (based on index and operation) are used.
 • As a result, even though 17 is a prime number in the natural sequence, it does not have a “natural” spot in any of the formulas. In other words, there is no equation such as kₓ = … ×17 + constant that fits with the rest of the chain.

──────────────────────────────
Q2: Next Prime Is 23

After using 19 (in the k₁₁ formula), the next prime in order among those “used” turns out to be 23. Indeed, we already have:
 k₁₄ = k₉×23 – 197.
Thus the pattern of primes used so far is: 7, then 11, then 13, then (skipping) 17, then 19, and now 23.

──────────────────────────────
Q3: What About k₁₅ and 29?

Following the observed pattern it is reasonable to conclude that the next formula will involve the next candidate prime. Since after 23 the next odd prime is 29 (again skipping over any primes not “naturally” assigned a spot in the chain), one expects that:
 k₁₅ will be defined by a formula of the general form
  k₁₅ = (some earlier k‑value) × 29 + C,
where the constant C is chosen so that the resulting value “fits” into the overall puzzle.

For example, one might test various candidates for the multiplier (the “previous term”). If we follow a similar structure to earlier formulas—
 • In k₈ the multiplier was taken from k₅;
 • In k₁₁ it came from k₆;
 • In k₁₄ it came from k₉—
one might try taking the same “slot” (say, using a term like k₉ or another appropriate earlier value) for k₁₅. That is, one plausible candidate would be:
 k₁₅ = 29 × (a chosen previous k-value) + C.
Without knowing all the numerical details of every k‑value in the chain it isn’t possible to “solve” uniquely for k₁₅ numerically. However, the structure does strongly suggest that the next prime entering the formulas will be 29.

──────────────────────────────
Summary

1. The puzzle’s design assigns primes at specific steps so that although the natural sequence of odd primes is 7, 11, 13, 17, 19, … only 7, 11, 13, (skipping) 17, then 19 and 23 appear.
2. Since k₁₄ already uses 23, it follows that the next prime in line—29—should be introduced at k₁₅.
3. Thus one expects a formula like
  k₁₅ = (an earlier term) × 29 + C,
with the details determined by consistency with the rest of the chain.

──────────────────────────────
